body:
<!-- Answer -->
This is a known accessibility issue in Storybook 8.x: the core tab components (like those used for Controls, Actions, Interactions, etc.) do not set the required `aria-selected` attribute on tab elements. As a result, screen readers‚Äîespecially Narrator on Windows/Edge‚Äîmay announce all tabs as "selected" or fail to announce the correct state, matching what you‚Äôre seeing. This gap is confirmed in multiple issues and is tracked for future improvement, but is not yet fixed in 8.x ([issue #32235](https://github.com/storybookjs/storybook/issues/32235), [issue #23640](https://github.com/storybookjs/storybook/issues/23640), [issue #26674](https://github.com/storybookjs/storybook/issues/26674)).

As a workaround, you can patch your local Storybook tab components to add `aria-selected={active}` to each tab button, following [WAI-ARIA Authoring Practices](https://www.w3.org/WAI/ARIA/apg/patterns/tabs/). For example, in your tab rendering code:

```jsx
<button
  role="tab"
  aria-selected={isSelected}
  // ...other props
>
  Tab label
</button>
```

This will ensure screen readers announce the correct selected state. Storybook is actively working on accessibility improvements for future releases (9.x+), so keep an eye on updates if you want a built-in fix.

If you‚Äôre using custom tab components in your stories, make sure they also follow this pattern. If the issue only appears in your own components and not in the default Storybook UI, please provide a minimal reproduction so we can help further.

issue.body:
Fixes screen reader announcing incorrect selected state on non-selected tabs. Added aria-selected attribute to TabButton components to properly communicate tab state to assistive technologies like Windows Narrator.

Closes #32654

## What I did
Added `aria-selected` attribute to TabButton components in the Tabs component to fix accessibility issues where screen readers (Windows Narrator) were announcing incorrect "selected" state on non-selected tabs.

The fix includes:
- `aria-selected={active}` - Properly communicates selected state to screen readers

## Checklist for Contributors

### Testing

#### The changes in this PR are covered in the following automated tests:
- [ ] stories
- [ ] unit tests
- [ ] integration tests
- [ ] end-to-end tests

#### Manual testing

**Manual testing is required for this accessibility fix.**

Testing steps:
1. Run a sandbox: `yarn start` 
2. Open Storybook in browser (http://localhost:6006)
3. Enable Windows Narrator (Ctrl + Win + Enter)
4. Navigate to any story with tabs (e.g., Controls tab)
5. Press Tab key to navigate to tab buttons
6. Verify Narrator announces:
   - Active tab: "Controls, tab, selected, 1 of X"
   - Inactive tab: "Interactions, tab, 2 of X" (WITHOUT "selected")

**Tested on:**
- OS: Windows 11 (24H2, Build 26407.5000)
- Browser: Edge 136.0.3240.92
- Screen Reader: Narrator

**Result:** ‚úÖ Screen reader now correctly announces selected/not selected state on tabs.

### Documentation

      [MIGRATION.MD](https://github.com/storybookjs/storybook/blob/next/MIGRATION.md)

**Note:** No documentation update needed as this is an internal accessibility fix with no API changes.

body:
Thank you for the detailed explanation and references.

We acknowledge that this is a known accessibility issue in Storybook 8.x and appreciate the suggested workaround. We‚Äôll try implementing the aria-selected attribute fix locally to verify if it resolves the incorrect state announcement by screen readers.

We‚Äôll also continue to monitor the linked GitHub issues and upcoming Storybook 9.x releases for the official fix.

@msftedad FYI we have a major PR open for accessibility, which is planned for Storybook 10.1: https://github.com/storybookjs/storybook/pull/32458.

On that branch, we've rewritten tablists and the selected tab should now be `aria-selected`. It would be lovely if you could give this branch a go and check if indeed it behaves as you intended.

Other fixes on the branch include handling of buttons, tooltips, popovers and toolbars, as well as misc small fixes and partial fixes for the problems in ArgsTable. We still have work planned to rewrite the sidebar, to create a distinct menu component, etc.

You can see the accessibility roadmap here: https://github.com/orgs/storybookjs/projects/23/views/1

I will close the issue now as fixed in Storybook 10.1 (knowing that we won't be able to backport most of the fixes on that branch). If you feel that the linked PR does not properly fix the issue, feel free to reopen it!
